image.altText: Smoke is coming from Gaza following Israeli strikes.

items.synopsis: The Israel Defense Forces take to Telegram to confirm earlier reports from the United Nations that the IDF is warning 1.1 million Gazans to evacuate to the south by midnight. Follow live

title.children: Israel Defense Forces warn over 1 million Gazans to relocate to the south

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) have taken to Telegram to confirm earlier reports from the United Nations saying Israeli military warned Gazans to evacuate to the south by midnight. "The IDF calls for the evacuation of all civilians of Gaza City from their homes southwards for their own safety and protection and move to the area south of the Wadi Gaza," the statement reads. "Civilians of Gaza City, evacuate south for your own safety and the safety of your families and distance yourself from Hamas terrorists who are using you as human shields." IDF spokesman Lieutenant Jonathan Conricus took to X to say that IDF did not want to target Gazan civilians. He reiterated that Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours. "We understand that this will take time," he said. "It is not an easy process. "The aim of this evacuation is simply to save lives." Mr Conricus also said Israel was liaising with UN authorities and remained "fully committed" to obeying international conflict law.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF confirms call for civilians from Gaza to evacuate south

children.content: The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) have taken to Telegram to confirm earlier reports from the United Nations saying Israeli military warned Gazans to evacuate to the south by midnight.
"The IDF calls for the evacuation of all civilians of Gaza City from their homes southwards for their own safety and protection and move to the area south of the Wadi Gaza," the statement reads.
"Civilians of Gaza City, evacuate south for your own safety and the safety of your families and distance yourself from Hamas terrorists who are using you as human shields."
IDF spokesman Lieutenant Jonathan Conricus took to X to say that IDF did not want to target Gazan civilians.
He reiterated that Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours.
"We understand that this will take time," he said.
"It is not an easy process.
"The aim of this evacuation is simply to save lives."
Mr Conricus also said Israel was liaising with UN authorities and remained "fully committed" to obeying international conflict law.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's ambassador to the UN Gilad Erdan has slammed the UN over its response to Israel warning 1.1 million Palestinians living in the north of the Gaza Strip to evacuate by midnight to the south. UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said earlier that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences". "The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said. Mr Erdan hit back by saying that "the UN's response to Israel's early warning to the residents of Gaza is a disgrace!". Mr Erdan said the UN should focus on condemning Hamas and supporting Israel's right to self-defence. "For many years, the UN turned a blind eye to the arming of Hamas and its use of civilian populations and infrastructure in the Gaza Strip for murder and for stockpiling its weapons," he said. Salama Marouf, head of the Hamas government media office, said the relocation warning was an attempt by Israel "to broadcast and pass on fake propaganda, aiming to sow confusion among citizens and harm our internal cohesion." He added: "We urge our citizens not to engage in these attempts." Reuters/ABC
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's ambassador to the UN slams response to Israel warning 1.1 million Gazans to evacuate

children.content: Israel's ambassador to the UN Gilad Erdan has slammed the UN over its response to
Israel warning 1.1 million Palestinians living in the north of the Gaza Strip to evacuate by midnight to the south
Mr Erdan called the UN's response a 'disgrace'
(Reuters: Mike Segar)
UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said earlier that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences".
"The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said.
Mr Erdan hit back by saying that "the UN's response to Israel's early warning to the residents of Gaza is a disgrace!".
Mr Erdan said the UN should focus on condemning Hamas and supporting Israel's right to self-defence.
"For many years, the UN turned a blind eye to the arming of Hamas and its use of civilian populations and infrastructure in the Gaza Strip for murder and for stockpiling its weapons," he said.

Salama Marouf, head of the Hamas government media office, said the relocation warning was an attempt by Israel "to broadcast and pass on fake propaganda, aiming to sow confusion among citizens and harm our internal cohesion."
He added: "We urge our citizens not to engage in these attempts."
Reuters/ABC

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations says it has been told by the Israeli military that some 1.1 million Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours. However, UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences". "The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said. Mr Dujarric said the order by the Israeli military also applied to all UN staff and those sheltered in UN facilities, including schools, health centres and clinics.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli military warns over 1 million Gazans to relocate south, United Nations says

children.content: The United Nations says it has been told by the Israeli military that some
1.1 million
Palestinians in Gaza should relocate to the enclave's south within the next 24 hours.
However, UN spokesman
Stephane Dujarric
said that it would be "impossible for such a movement to take place without devastating humanitarian consequences".
"The United Nations strongly appeals for any such order, if confirmed, to be rescinded, avoiding what could transform what is already a tragedy into a calamitous situation," he said.
Mr Dujarric said the order by the Israeli military also applied to all UN staff and those sheltered in UN facilities, including schools, health centres and clinics.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Speaking about the trends expected on Saturday night when referendum votes are counted, ABC chief election analyst Antony Green says votes should come in from small rural booths first, where the Yes campaign has been polling poorly. He said the Yes vote would start low on that basis, but then rise. "What we will be watching for on the night is when does this stop rising, and I would expect with about 10 per cent of the votes counted in each state, the trend will solidify by that point," Mr Green told Background Briefing. He said he would be watching for the trend in the cities when those votes come in, with polling showing the Yes vote was higher in inner cities than the outer suburbs. "No state will vote 'Yes' unless the capital city votes 'Yes', so we will be waiting for a good sample of votes from cities like Sydney and Melbourne, and then looking at where they are from in those two cities" he said. "If the result is as clear cut as some of the polls, then we should have a very early call in most states. "I would say say one hour after the close of counting in each state, unless its close, we should be able to call each state."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Election analyst Antony Green says result in each state could be clear within an hour

props.alt: Antony Green in a suit speaking in a studio

children.content: Antony Green.
(ABC News)
Speaking about the trends expected on Saturday night when referendum votes are counted, ABC chief election analyst
Antony Green
says votes should come in from small rural booths first, where the Yes campaign has been polling poorly.
He said the Yes vote would start low on that basis, but then rise.

"What we will be watching for on the night is when does this stop rising, and I would expect with about 10 per cent of the votes counted in each state, the trend will solidify by that point," Mr Green told
Background Briefing
He said he would be watching for the trend in the cities when those votes come in, with polling showing the Yes vote was higher in inner cities than the outer suburbs.

"No state will vote 'Yes' unless the capital city votes 'Yes', so we will be waiting for a good sample of votes from cities like Sydney and Melbourne, and then looking at where they are from in those two cities" he said.
"If the result is as clear cut as some of the polls, then we should have a very early call in most states.
"I would say say one hour after the close of counting in each state, unless its close, we should be able to call each state."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Voice referendum debate has been dominated by misinformation. One of the arguments being put forward by the No campaign is that First Nations people already have a voice. No campaign group Fair Australia singles out the little known government agency, the National Indigenous Australians Agency (NIAA), as an existing voice. "Indigenous Australians already have a voice through the NIAA," said No campaigner Damien Pace while handing out "Vote No" pamphlets in the inner-city suburb of Ultimo last week. The NIAA carries out government policy funding and implementing programs to improve the lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people around the country. Like any public service department or agency, it does provide advice to government, but that is not its main role. Yes23 co-chair Arrernte and Kalkadoon woman Rachel Perkins says it's a "myth" that the NIAA is a voice. Constitutional expert, Professor Cheryl Saunders from the University of Melbourne, agrees that the NIAA is not a voice to parliament. "It's a completely different body to the Voice," she told the ABC. "It doesn't give advice to the parliament, it's a body that advises government." Read more below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The No campaign says the NIAA is an existing voice to parliament. Here's why it's not

featuredLink.title: The No campaign says this little-known agency is an existing voice to parliament. Here's why it's not

children.content: The Voice referendum debate has been dominated by misinformation. One of the arguments being put forward by the No campaign is that First Nations people already have a voice.
No campaign group Fair Australia singles out the little known government agency, the
National Indigenous Australians Agency (NIAA)
, as an existing voice.
"Indigenous Australians already have a voice through the NIAA," said No campaigner Damien Pace while handing out "Vote No" pamphlets in the inner-city suburb of Ultimo last week.
The NIAA carries out government policy funding and implementing programs to improve the lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people around the country.
Like any public service department or agency, it does provide advice to government, but that is not its main role.
Yes23 co-chair Arrernte and Kalkadoon woman
Rachel Perkins
says it's a "myth" that the NIAA is a voice.
Constitutional expert,
Professor Cheryl Saunders
from the University of Melbourne, agrees that the NIAA is not a voice to parliament.
"It's a completely different body to the Voice," she told the ABC.
"It doesn't give advice to the parliament, it's a body that advises government."
Read more below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Evelyn Manfield Leading No campaigner Warren Mundine says he's comfortable Australia will vote No in the referendum, but he still wants people to make sure they turn up and vote if they haven't yet done so. "I've just flown in from Tasmania the day before and I have been in Adelaide, South Australia, [and] everything feels comfortable, but we've got to have people turn up today, we've got to have people vote," he said after casting his vote. Mr Mundine maintained the country did not need to have a referendum in the first place and the money could have been better spent on education, employment and housing. He said after the referendum, he would work with campaigners from the Yes side to fix the struggles Aboriginal people face.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Warren Mundine casts his vote, says he's 'comfortable' Australia will vote No

props.alt: A close up of Warren speaking at the National Press Club

children.content: Warren Mundine
(AAP: Lukas Coch)
By Evelyn Manfield
Leading No campaigner
Warren Mundine
says he's comfortable Australia will vote No in the referendum, but he still wants people to make sure they turn up and vote if they haven't yet done so.

"I've just flown in from Tasmania the day before and I have been in Adelaide, South Australia, [and] everything feels comfortable, but we've got to have people turn up today, we've got to have people vote," he said after casting his vote.
Mr Mundine maintained the country did not need to have a referendum in the first place and the money could have been better spent on education, employment and housing.
He said after the referendum, he would work with campaigners from the Yes side to fix the struggles Aboriginal people face.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The AFL has confirmed St Kilda has not matched Essendon's bid, the Saints will receive pick 21 as compensation and Jade Gresham will become a Bomber. Now things can really start to get moving.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jade Gresham is officially a Bomber

children.content: (Getty Images)
The AFL has confirmed St Kilda has not matched Essendon's bid, the Saints will receive pick 21 as compensation and Jade Gresham will become a Bomber.
Now things can really start to get moving.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Continuing our series looking at the top draft prospects of 2023, we'll turn our attentions to a thrilling small forward set to become a fan favourite. There is no player in this draft as skilful as Nick Watson. He kicks goals most players couldn't dream of pulling off. He's a small forward who works hand all over the ground, and has had proven impact as a pinch-hitting midfielder. Sounds pretty good, right? What's the downside? The knock on Watson is he is 170cm tall. That makes him shorter than Caleb Daniel. But as Daniel, Brent Harvey and so many others have proven over the journey, height matters little when your football talent is immense enough. And in Watson's case, it certainly is. Concerns over his height won't be enough to deter clubs from making him a top-10 pick, but it might be enough to spook clubs right up the very top end. What is certain is that whoever picks him up is going to be treated to plenty of highlights, and one set of fans is going to have a new cult hero to love.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Nick Watson

children.content: Continuing our series looking at the top draft prospects of 2023, we'll turn our attentions to a thrilling small forward set to become a fan favourite.

There is no player in this draft as skilful as Nick Watson. He kicks goals most players couldn't dream of pulling off. He's a small forward who works hand all over the ground, and has had proven impact as a pinch-hitting midfielder.
(Getty Images)
Sounds pretty good, right? What's the downside?
The knock on Watson is he is 170cm tall. That makes him shorter than Caleb Daniel.
But as Daniel, Brent Harvey and so many others have proven over the journey, height matters little when your football talent is immense enough. And in Watson's case, it certainly is.
(Getty Images)
Concerns over his height won't be enough to deter clubs from making him a top-10 pick, but it might be enough to spook clubs right up the very top end.
What is certain is that whoever picks him up is going to be treated to plenty of highlights, and one set of fans is going to have a new cult hero to love.
